text: time for fondant my favorite part of
decorating a cake and you want to know
how I do it you're about to find out for
this cake which is a 9-inch round cake
I'm using two and a half pounds of
fondant the first thing you need to do
when working with fondant is to knead it
really well you want to get out all the
air bubbles you want to sort of soften
it if you live in a hot climate and you
find that your fondant is getting sticky
while you need it you can put a little
bit of vegetable shortening on your
hands if your fondant is sticking to
your surface while kneading you can just
use a bit of icing sugar sprinkled onto
your surface and knead that into your
fondant as you go to stop that from
happening fondant is simply a sugar
dough mainly made up of different types
of sugar and it's used to cover cakes
it's great on novelty cakes you just
roll it out and cover a cake and smooth
it on as opposed to icing a cake with a
palette knife when you're happy with
your kneading what I like to do is save
myself a bit of work by bringing all the
seams down underneath your ball of
fondant and then flattening out your
fondant just to help you roll it out
better so now what we're going to do is
done a nice layer of icing sugar don't
worry because we can scrape away and
brush away the excess now place your
fondant down onto your icing sugar I
like to put a little bit of icing sugar
on the surface of my fondant just a
light sprinkling and then I actually
sort of brush most of it away just
because I don't want it to stick to my
rolling pin I like to use a regular
rolling pin to roll out fondant and what
I like to do is try and roll in every
direction at first so back and forth
side to side and then diagonally just so
we can maintain that round circle of
fondant as we're rolling you do have to
press in order to roll it down but I try
to go a little bit gently just to keep
it nice and even I don't want to push
all the fondant out to the edge and have
some parts be thinner and some be
thicker try to maintain an even roll
and as you roll you might notice air
bubbles like this baby
use a pin a nice little sharp pin and
just insert it on an angle slowly into
the fondant into the air bubble and then
use your hand to brush the air out of
that hole direct the air out of that
little pinhole
now keep rolling your fondant and at
this point what I like to do is start to
roll from the center out this is a great
time to scrape away any of the excess
icing sugar you have under your fondant
I use a plastic scraper and what you do
is just push it up just like that I can
tell that my fondant circle isn't big
enough just by looking at it it has to
be large enough to cover the top as well
as all around the sides of the cake
because we're going to pick up this
whole piece of fondant and drape it over
the cake so keep rolling I like to roll
my fondant 1/8 of an inch thick that
does take some practice at first so
every single time just try to get it a
little bit thinner than the time before
this is what I call game time cake time
I call this cake time so you want to
work quickly when you're picking up your
fondant this is very important it is
heavy it can slip it can rip it can drop
it can crack a lot of things can go
wrong at this point and you don't want
that to happen I like to pick up my
fondant with a French rolling pin which
unlike this rolling pin doesn't spin you
can pick up on it with this the problem
is it's heavy so when you pick it up
you're fine I might just roll right off
and you don't I learned that the hard
way too I'm going to save you the
trouble just rest your French rolling
pin in the middle of your circle fold it
over this is a good time if there's too
much icing sugar just brush it away
because that will sort of stop your
fondant room sticking to your cake pick
it up
be very careful when you do this okay
now working quickly drape this fondant
over your cake you want to get to the
corners first that's the most important
glue them down just with this part of
your hand work down the sides of your
fondant you're going to get folds with a
fondant sort of overlaps and what you
want to do stretch them out and use the
palm of your hand to just lightly press
it against your cake so when you get to
a fold you sort of pull the fold apart
make it flat and then work it toward
your cake and you're also sort of
pressing down so that the excess fondant
is moving away from your cake and you're
also moving any air bubbles trapped
under down and away from your cake I
just like to cut away any excess fondant
just because it's getting in the way now
it's time for a fondant smoother what I
like to do is work from the top outer
edge and smooth inward that's what I
like to do you will usually have an air
bubble on the top of your cake once
again use your trusty pin and just
insert it into the air bubble and move
the air out of the hole and there you go
now you're going to use your fondant
smoother to smooth out the sides of the
cake I like to start at the top and you
want to just press the flat surface onto
your fondant pressing it into your cake
and then I like to sort of move down
this way if there's air I'm pushing it
down once again and when you're at the
bottom the base of the cake you really
sort of want to not only press into the
cake but press down onto your cake board
now what I want to do is sharpen up the
edges of this cake just a bit so what
I'm going to do is use two fondant
sneakers
what I like to do is place one on top of
my cake that sort of pushes the fondant
outward and gives me a nice sort of
sealing and then this second fondant
smoother will work up toward the top
financier there
so I'm starting to see sharper edges on
my cake and really what I'm doing is
using this smoother as a sealing and
pulling this smoother up with the
fondant to meet the other one and you
also want to take your fondant smoother
and go back around because we've been
using a flat surface up and down we
might have created some ridges so I'm
going to smooth those out working with
the shape of the cake there is a lot of
air at this crease a good way to handle
that rather than a pin is to just lift
from the bottom and release that air
down so once our fondant is nice and
smooth and you're happy the next step is
to cut away the excess you should see a
nice clean line down at the base of your
cake and before you cut away the excess
keep in mind that fondant has elasticity
so sometimes it bounces back after you
cut it so what I like to do is take my
fingertips and actually push this excess
fondant into the cake before I cut it
now I'm going to cut away the excess
fondant I'm going to use a very sharp
paring knife so you want to cut right on
that clean line as close to the cake as
possible cut slowly and cut mainly with
the point of the sharp knife now just
pull away all your excess fondant this
cake is as smooth as I can get it for
now
what I'm going to do is put it in my
fridge to chill for 30 minutes it is
true that the fridge makes fondant sweat
I have a special fridge that has been
altered not to do that here's a tip for
you guys if you have a regular fridge
what I used to do was empty a space in
my fridge and turn it down to the lowest
setting possible and I would only put my
cake in there for about 10 minutes if
that's not an option for you at all just
set your cake aside so that the fun if
you firm up a little bit at least on the
surface my cake is covered and bonded
it's slightly chilled I'm going to show
you how to cover up these unsightly
creases if you should have any this is
just royal icing which I usually have on
hand just take a little bit of royal
icing on a small offset pallet knife and
then just smooth it out
there we go my crease is all patched up
now I can move on to decorating
